info.senderName: NWS Albuquerque (Northern and Central New Mexico)
info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 27 at 3:50PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: ...ARCTIC BLAST BRINGS WINTRY MIX AND SUB-FREEZING TEMPERATURES TO EASTERN NEW MEXICO UP TO THE CENTRAL MOUNTAIN CHAIN... A potent backdoor cold front is forecast to surge down the eastern plains of New Mexico, entering from Colorado to Colfax and Union Counties Saturday evening and reaching the Central Mountain chain to Roswell Sunday morning. A sharp drop in temperatures accompanied by a light mix of winter precipitation will accompany this cold front. Precipitation will start as rain before quickly transitioning to a mix of freezing rain and sleet and then finally snow. Accumulations will be little to none, but still enough to threaten slick and icy roads across the northeastern and east- central plains Sunday morning. Freezing temperatures are forecast to persist across the northeastern and east-central plains for 24 to 36 hours as high temperatures will struggle to break freezing Sunday afternoon. These areas of New Mexico should make preparations to protect people, pets, pipes, and plants. Those with travel plans should stay up-to-date on the latest forecast information. While the eastern plains see steadily improving conditions through the day Sunday, light snow showers will enter the northern mountains of New Mexico Sunday afternoon and evening. Strong east canyon winds reaching peak gusts of 35 to 45 mph will also be possible into Santa Fe and Albuquerque through most of the day Sunday. Accumulations of 3 to 9 inches will be possible through the Sangre de Cristo Mountains above 9,000 feet allowing for slick winter travel conditions here. Snow flurries will be possible in surrounding valley areas, including down into the Santa Fe and Albuquerque metro areas Sunday night into early Monday morning.
